OVERVIEW: The Mikado series consists of very deep somewhat poorly drained soils that formed in loamy glacial till on ground moraines. Permeability is moderate in the upper part and very slow in the middle part and moderately slow in the lower part. Slopes range from 0 to 3 percent.  Mean annual precipitation is about 30 inches, and the mean annual temperature is about 44 degrees F.

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Mikado sandy loam on a 1 percent slope on a moraine in a wooded area. (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise stated.)
Oe--2 to 0 inches; partially decomposed forest litter; abrupt smooth boundary. (0 to 3 inches thick)
A--0 to 5 inches; very dark gray (10YR 3/1) sandy loam; gray (10YR 5/1) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; friable; many fine and many medium roots; about 2 percent gravel; slightly acid; abrupt smooth boundary. (3 to 5 inches thick)
E--5 to 13 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam; common fine distinct yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) and strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) mottles; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; firm; common fine roots in worm channels; common fine vesicular pores; about 2 percent gravel; neutral; clear wavy boundary. (5 to 8 inches thick)
E/B--13 to 23 inches; brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam (E); occupies about 70 percent of the horizon as tongues surrounding peds of brown (7.5YR 5/4) loam (Bt); common fine prominent strong brown (7.5YR 5/6), and grayish brown (10YR 5/2) mottles; weak very coarse platy structure; firm; few fine roots between peds; many fine vesicular pores; about 2 percent gravel; neutral; clear irregular boundary.
B/E--23 to 28 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) loam (Bt); occupies about 70 percent of the horizon surrounded by brown (10YR 5/3) sandy loam (E); common fine distinct yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) and prominent grayish brown (10YR 5/2) mottles; weak very coarse prismatic structure parting to weak very coarse platy structure; firm; few fine roots between peds; many fine vesicular pores; about 2 percent gravel; neutral; clear wavy boundary. (Combined thickness of the E/B and B/E horizons are 14 to 20 inches thick.)
Bt--28 to 35 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) loam; common medium prominent yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) mottles on ped faces, and few fine prominent grayish brown (10YR 5/2) mottles in clay skins and near roots; weak very coarse platy structure; very firm; few fine flattened roots between peds; many fine vesicular pores; common brown (7.5YR) clay films greater than 1mm thick on ped faces; about 5 percent gravel; neutral; clear wavy boundary. (5 to 7 inches thick)
BCd--35 to 44 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) loam; few fine prominent gray (N 6/0) and common fine distinct strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) mottles; weak very coarse platy structure; very firm; few faint brown (7.5YR 5/4) clay films on plate surfaces; about 5 percent gravel; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline; clear wavy boundary. (0 to 9 inches thick)
C--44 to 60 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/3) loam; common fine distinct strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) mottles; massive; friable; common white (7.5YR 8/0) lime coats throughout; about 5 percent gravel; slightly effervescent; moderately alkaline.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Alcona County, Michigan; about 2.5 miles east of the village of Glennie; 2,565 feet south and 2,565 feet west of the northeast corner of sec., T. 25 N., R. 6 E.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The thickness of the solum ranges from 35 to 50 inches. Depth to free carbonates ranges from  30 to 40 inches.  Gravel content ranges from 0 to 5 percent throughout. Cobble content ranges from 0 to 3 percent throughout. The solum ranges from slightly acid to moderately alkaline.
The A horizon has hue of 7.5YR, 10YR, or is neutral and chroma of 0 or 1. The E horizon has hue of 2.5Y or 10YR, and chroma of 2 or 3.
The E part of the E/B and B/E horizons has hue of 5YR, 7.5YR, 10YR, or is neutral; value of 5 or 6, and chroma of 0 to 3. The B part of the E/B and B/E horizons has hue of 5YR and 7.5YR, value of 4 or 5, and chroma of 3 to 6. It is loam or clay loam. The E/B and B/E horizons exhibit some characteristics of a fragipan; it is firm when moist and hard when dry and has some brittleness.
The Bt horizon has hue of 5YR or 7.5YR; value of 5 or 6, and chroma of 3 or 4. It is loam or clay loam.
The C horizon has hue of 5YR or 7.5YR; value of 5 or 6, and chroma of 3 or 4.  It is loam or clay loam.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no other series in the same family. Closely related soils are the Iosco, Glennie (T), Riggsville and Selfridge soils. Iosco and Riggsville soils do not have a fragipan, contain more sand in the upper subsoil and have a spodic horizon. Glennie soils are moderately well drained and well drained and are on higher positions on the landscape. Selfridge soils are from a mesic temperature regime.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: The Mikado soils are on ground moraines. Slopes are 0 to 3 percent. The mean annual precipitation ranges from 27 to 32 inches, and the mean annual temperature ranges from 40 to 44 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Glennie and Lupton soils.  The well drained and moderately well drained Glennie soils are in the same drainage sequence and occur on higher positions on the landscape.  Lupton soils are very poorly drained organic soils that occur in closed depressions.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Somewhat poorly drained. Surface runoff is slow. Permeability is moderate in the upper part, very slow in the middle part and moderately slow in the lower part.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: A major portion of the soil is forestland. Tree species include paper birch, bigtooth aspen, quaking aspen, red maple, black ash, eastern white pine, and balsam fir. Other areas are used as pasture and cropland. Common crops include hay, alfalfa and corn.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: The northeastern quarter of the lower peninsula of Michigan. The series is of minor extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: AMHERST, MASSACHUSETTS

ORIGIN.content: SERIES PROPOSED: Alcona County, Michigan, 1990. The source of the name is a village in Alcona County.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are: ochric epipedon - the zone from the surface to 5 inches (A horizon); albic horizon - the zone from 5 to 28 inches (E horizon and E part of E/B horizon); argillic horizon - the zone from 23 to 35 inches (B part of the B/E and Bt horizons).
For laboratory data on representative pedon see Michigan Technological University NO. 89MI-001-003.
The Mikado soils formed in dense fractured glacial till that is underlain by coarse textured stratified glaciofluvium at depths greater than 10 feet.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
